Instruction: What are the rules and regulations regarding mediation in consumer disputes in India, and what are the procedures for mediation cells and panels of mediators?
Response:
The Consumer Protection (Mediation) Rules, 2020, provide for the rules and regulations regarding mediation in consumer disputes in India. According to these rules, every Mediation Cell set up in a Commission shall have a panel of mediators on the recommendation of a selection committee consisting of the President and a member of that Commission.

The Mediation Cell shall have such support staff as may be decided by the President of that Commission in consultation with the concerned Government, and that Government shall provide all administrative assistance and infrastructure facilities required by the Commission.

Certain matters shall not be referred to mediation, including matters relating to medical negligence resulting in grievous injury or death, cases involving serious and specific allegations of fraud, fabrication of documents, forgery, impersonation, coercion, and cases relating to prosecution for criminal and non-compoundable offences.

The Commission before which the case is pending may choose not to refer it to mediation if it appears to the Commission that no elements of a settlement exist which may be acceptable to the parties or that mediation is otherwise not appropriate having regard to the circumstances of the case and the respective positions of the parties.

Where the Commission refers the parties to mediation, the complainant shall be entitled to receive full amount of application fee paid in respect of such complaint, if a settlement is reached between such parties. The parties shall not initiate any arbitral or judicial proceedings in respect of a matter which is the subject-matter of the mediation and also when such parties have expressly undertaken not to initiate any such proceeding.

The Consumer Protection (Consumer Commission Procedure) Regulations, 2020, provide for the procedure to be followed by the Consumer Commission in disposing of complaints, appeals, and revision petitions. The Consumer Commission shall have the arrangements as to depict it distinct from a court. The Commission shall have a Registrar who shall be the head of the ministerial establishment of the Commission and shall exercise such powers and functions as are conferred upon him by the President of the Commission.

The Consumer Commission shall have the power to issue notice to the opposite parties or respondents, and the notice shall be served upon the opposite party or respondent along with copies of the complaint, memorandum of grounds of appeal or petition, as the case may be, and other documents filed.

"Phony malware" can be used to trick users into believing that their computer is infected with a virus and paying for fake malware removal tools that actually install malware on their computer. This can result in users losing money or having their personal data compromised.

Overall, these dark patterns can have serious consequences for consumers, and it is essential to prohibit them to protect consumer rights and prevent unfair trade practices.

Instruction: What are the rules and regulations regarding the functioning of the Consumer Commission, including its administrative control, inspection, and uploading of orders and pending matters?
Response:
The Consumer Commission has rules and regulations regarding its functioning, including:

* Dress code: The President and members of the Consumer Commission shall wear simple and sober dress, and shall not wear flashy dress or dress displaying any affluence. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Hearing hours: The normal working hours of the Consumer Commission for hearing matters shall be from 10.30 a.m. to 1.00 p.m. and 2.00 p.m. to 4.30 p.m. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Cause list: The Consumer Commission shall display the cause list of cases to be heard on the notice board and on its website. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Institution of complaints, appeals, and revision petitions: The Consumer Commission has rules regarding the institution of complaints, appeals, and revision petitions, including the number of sets to be filed and the documents to be attached. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Scrutiny of complaints: The Consumer Commission shall scrutinize complaints and issue notices to the opposite parties. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Adjournment: The Consumer Commission shall record the reasons for any adjournment made by it, and shall impose costs for granting adjournment. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Hearing by benches: The Consumer Commission shall hear matters by benches, and shall refer complex questions of law to the President of the State Commission or the National Commission. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Arguments: The Consumer Commission shall hear arguments, and shall impose costs for not filing briefs. (220667-9-14.pdf)
* Refund of fee: The Consumer Commission shall refund the fee paid by the complainant if a settlement is reached between the parties. (220667-9-14.pdf)

Regarding administrative control, the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission has regulations regarding:

* Inspection of State Commission: The President or a member of the National Commission shall inspect each State Commission at least once in a calendar year. (220670-3-4.pdf)
* Inspection of District Commission: The President or a member of the State Commission shall inspect each District Commission under its administrative control at least once in a calendar year. (220670-3-4.pdf)
* Recommendation to State Government for administrative action: The President of the National Commission or the State Commission may recommend to the State Government for taking suitable administrative action against the President or a member of the State Commission or the District Commission. (220670-3-4.pdf)
* Uploading of orders: The State Commission and the District Commission shall upload final orders pronounced by them on their respective websites within three days of the pronouncement of such order. (220670-3-4.pdf)
* Uploading of pending matters: The State Commission and the District Commission shall upload the particulars of the pending matters on their respective websites by the 7th day of each month. (220670-3-4.pdf)

Instruction: What are the powers and functions of the Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019?
Response:
The Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) has the following powers and functions under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019:

* Protect, promote, and enforce the rights of consumers as a class, and prevent violation of consumer rights under the Act.
* Prevent unfair trade practices and ensure that no person engages in such practices.
* Ensure that no false or misleading advertisement is made of any goods or services that contravenes the provisions of the Act or the rules or regulations made thereunder.
* Inquire or cause an inquiry or investigation to be made into violations of consumer rights or unfair trade practices, either suo motu or on a complaint received or on the directions from the Central Government.
* File complaints before the District Commission, the State Commission, or the National Commission, as the case may be, under the Act.
* Review the matters relating to, and the factors inhibiting enjoyment of, consumer rights, including safeguards provided for the protection of consumers under any other law for the time being in force, and recommend appropriate remedial measures for their effective implementation.
* Recommend the adoption of international covenants and best international practices on consumer rights to ensure effective enforcement of consumer rights.
* Undertake and promote research in the field of consumer rights.
* Spread and promote awareness on consumer rights.
* Encourage non-Governmental organizations and other institutions working in the field of consumer rights to co-operate and work with consumer protection agencies.

Instruction: What are the conditions for a non-misleading and valid advertisement, according to the Guidelines for Prevention of Misleading Advertisements and Endorsements?
Response:
According to the Guidelines for Prevention of Misleading Advertisements and Endorsements, an advertisement is considered non-misleading and valid if it meets the following conditions:

* Contains truthful and honest representation
* Does not mislead consumers by exaggerating the accuracy, scientific validity or practical usefulness or capability or performance or service of the goods or product
* Does not present rights conferred on consumers by any law as a distinctive feature of advertiser’s offer
* Does not suggest that the claims made in such advertisement are universally accepted if there is a significant division of informed or scientific opinion pertaining to such claims
* Does not mislead about the nature or extent of the risk to consumers’ personal security, or that of their family if they fail to purchase the advertised goods, product or service
* Ensures that the claims that have not been independently substantiated but are based merely on the content of a publication do not mislead consumers
* Complies with the provisions contained in any other sector specific law and the rules and regulations made thereunder

Instruction: What are some examples of "dark patterns" that are prohibited under the Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns, 2023?
Response:
Some examples of "dark patterns" that are prohibited under the Guidelines for Prevention and Regulation of Dark Patterns, 2023 include:

* "False Urgency", which means falsely stating or implying the sense of urgency or scarcity so as to mislead a user into making an immediate purchase or taking an immediate action. Examples include showing false popularity of a product or service to manipulate user decision, or stating that quantities of a particular product or service are more limited than they actually are.
* "Basket sneaking", which means inclusion of additional items such as products, services, payments to charity or donation at the time of checkout from a platform, without the consent of the user, such that the total amount payable by the user is more than the amount payable for the product or service chosen by the user. Examples include automatic addition of paid ancillary services with a pre-ticked box or otherwise to the cart when a consumer is purchasing a product or service, or automatically adding travel insurance while a user purchases a flight ticket.
